issues.description: Method name mismatch for the Farm song method: the problem statement (and UML) repeatedly refers to a public method named printFarmSong(), but the template repository and the reference solution implement and use a method named singFarmSong(). This naming inconsistency can confuse students about which method to implement and may cause tests or example code to call a different method name than the student implemented.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent across all artifacts. EITHER change the problem statement and UML to refer to singFarmSong() (preferred, since template and solution already use that name), OR change the template and solution to implement printFarmSong() and update example/test code accordingly. Ensure all references (text, UML, template method signature, and tests/examples) use the same method name.

issues.description: The problem statement (and UML) instructs students to implement a method named printFarmSong() (see UML and Part 3 instructions), but both the template and the provided solution use the method name singFarmSong() in Farm.java. This naming mismatch (printFarmSong vs. singFarmSong) refers to the same conceptual operation (playing/printing the farm song) and can confuse students: they may implement printFarmSong() that does not match the starter code, or they may search for a method that the instructions name differently than the template. The inconsistency breaks a direct mapping from the requirement to the provided code and the reference solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Use a single consistent name across problem statement, template, and solution. Either update the problem text and UML to refer to singFarmSong(), or rename the method in the template and solution from singFarmSong() to printFarmSong() (and update any calls, e.g., Main). Prefer updating the problem statement to refer to singFarmSong() if changing code is undesirable, or rename the code to printFarmSong() if you want to match the UML wording.
